stem: A 6-year-old child with a history of asthma is brought to the emergency department with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial nursing intervention?

options.text: Administer a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) via nebulizer.
Call the healthcare provider to report the patient's condition.

rationale.correct: Administering a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) such as albuterol is the first-line treatment for acute asthma exacerbations. It helps to quickly dilate the airways and improve breathing.
rationale.mnemonic: ABC - Airway, Breathing, Circulation. In asthma, focus on opening the Airway first.
rationale.incorrect: While oxygen administration is important, it is secondary to bronchodilation in an acute asthma exacerbation. Albuterol will help open the airways to allow for better oxygenation. Calling the provider is important, but should not delay immediate treatment. Assessing peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) can be helpful, but administering medication is the priority.
rationale.questionTrap: The question traps the test taker into thinking about oxygen administration first, but bronchodilation is the priority.
clinicalPearls: In acute asthma exacerbations, bronchodilators are the priority.
Assess respiratory status frequently after administering bronchodilators.

itemContext.sbar: S: Alex Johnson, 6-year-old male, presents with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. History of asthma. B: Patient has a history of asthma, usually well-controlled with albuterol inhaler. A: Patient is currently wheezing and short of breath. Respiratory rate is 32, heart rate is 120, oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. O: See above.
